data.message: The latest progressive onslaught aimed at capitalism, liberty, freedom, individualism, etc. is not something new. "Takers" have been living off the "Givers" for many decades, always with a dimunition of society. Ayn Rand wrote a novel in 1957 called "Atlas Shrugged" that better than any other book showed the path to serfdom that progressives take a society. She offered solutions that emphasized individualism, reason,

data.message:
Do not expect consistency. Everything is a contradiction of everything else. Nothing exists but contradictions. 

Contradictions do not exist. Whenever you think that you are facing a contradiction, check your premises. You will find that one of them is wrong.

- Ayn Rand, Atlas Shrugged.

I found out recently that one of my FB friends dropped me, and anyone who is "friends" with me, because I listed Atlas Shrugged as one of my favorite books.  And it is, but my take on the novel is quite nuanced--I'm no Ann-Randian, but the book was my first exposure to why the capitalist system is a good system.  In my quasi-socialist family and hippie surroundings, I had never known.  And it did change my outlook.

"Whenever destroyers appear among men, they start
by destroying money, for money is men’s protection and the base of moral
existence.  Destroyers seize gold and
leave to its owners a counterfeit pile of paper.  This kills all objective standards and
delivers men into the arbitrary power of an arbitrary setter of values." - Ayn Rand, Atlas Shrugged.

Thanks to Neal Boortz for this list of recommended reading for liberals stuck in their 1960s time warp: The Law by Frederic Bastiat, The Camp of the Saints by Jean Raspail, Atlas Shrugged by Ayn Rand and The Road to Serfdom by F.A.Hayek.

data.message: Atlas shrugged, the movie. In theaters soon. Loved the book. Maybe some of those illiterate communist that call themselves Americans can watch this and learn.

In a 1974 essay, "Atlas Shrugged" author Ayn Rand observed that "Thanksgiving is a typically American holiday. Its essential, secular meaning is a celebration of successful production. It is a producers' holiday. The lavish meal is a symbol of the fact that abundant consumption is the result and reward of production."
Thanksgiving as per Ayn Rand.  God Bless America!
Just found a 95 cent copy of Atlas Shrugged in the bottom of Linda Jemison's bookcase. As much as we might disagree politically these days, she sure is fun to argue with when I'm home. Props mom.
